Award.AwardTitle: SEES Fellows: Understanding Farmers' Valuation of Environmental Services and Forest Sustainability: Governance and Institutions in the Selva Zoque, Mexico
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this Award from the NSF Science, Engineering and Education for Sustainability Fellows (SEES Fellows Program) Dr. Claudia Rodriguez-Solorzano from Dartmouth College will study the factors that govern individual farmers decision making when it comes to land-use decisions, how these farmers weigh the benefits of providing environmental services, balanced against benefits that they derive from using land for agricultural activities. This award has support from: the Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences, the Directorate for Biological Sciences, the Office of International and Integrative Activities, and the Office of Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

The proposed research project will contribute to local and global social-environmental sustainability by advancing our understanding about motivations of human behavior associated with the provision of environmental services. For this purpose the research will answer two interrelated questions: 1) how do governance and institutions affect farmers valuation of environmental services provided by forests? and 2) for those farmers who value environmental services, what factors influence their decisions on their land use? The project ties together current research on farmer behavior from anthropology, collective action and institutions from political science, and environmental services for economics. This multidisciplinary approach provides a platform for developing an empirically based framework for developing policies that will enhance sustainability of ecosystem service provision. The proposed extensive empirical work will provide opportunity to test and refine the framework.

This research uses the Selva Zoque, a highly biodiverse region of intact tropical forest in southern Mexico, as its laboratory. Divided among the states of Oaxaca, Veracruz, and Chiapas, different governance mechanisms are in place to support farmer provision of environmental services, including community-based management and protected areas.

Dr. Rodriguez-Solorzano will be working with collaborators Richard Howarth (Dartmouth College) and Eduardo Brondizio (Indiana University), as well as young scientists (research assistants and students) on this research.
This project is supported under the NSF Science, Engineering and Education for Sustainability Fellows (SEES Fellows) program, with the goal of helping to enable discoveries needed to inform actions that lead to environmental, energy and societal sustainability while creating the necessary workforce to address these challenges. With SEES Fellows support, this project will enable a promising early career researcher to establish themselves in an independent research career related to sustainability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Deforestation is an important driver of environmental change; it affects ecosystems’ ability to produce local and global environmental services, such as climate and hydrological regulation, soil conservation, water filtration, and CO2 storage. Farmers have been at the center of major international forest conservation and environmental sustainability policies, such as Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and forest Degradation (REDD), payments for environmental services (PES), and product certification. These incentive-based programs aim to meet global sustainability goals while aiding farmers’ livelihoods. Incentive-based programs represent a step forward when compared to older “command and control” policies. Yet, these policies are based on simplistic assumptions about farmers’ motivations. These policies assume that farmers’ sole interest is cash income, and constrain farmers to paid stewards of global environmental services. In this context farmers are expected to have low or no valuation of environmental services or to be unable to protect their forest due to high discount rates derived from their need to allocate scarce resources towards current consumption. Sustainability policies based on such assumptions ignore local benefits from environmental services and the influence that socio-economic factors, institutions, governance and farmers’ valuation of environmental services have on farmers’ behavior.

This research project questioned these assumptions about farmer motivation and behavior by focusing on the importance of institutions and governance. Through a comparative analysis of pathways of institutional development in two politically differentiated regions of a single ecological unit, the research finds that differences in conservation behavior between those regions are the result of differences in land tenure systems that pre-date modern conservation efforts. Differences in land tenure systems in the area of study resulted in different population densities, unequal tenure security and economic and political conditions. These factors influence farmers’ attitudes towards conservation. The findings of the research show that institutional legacies and governance influence farmers’ livelihood opportunities, as well as their valuation and conservation behavior related to ecosystem services (Rodriguez-Solorzano & Fleischman under review).

The data and findings of this research contribute to our understanding of the links between livelihoods, ecosystem services and social vulnerability. The knowledge produced by this research project will help to build theories about farmers’ decision making processes in biologically diverse regions, where the production of livelihoods, resilience to climate stimuli and ecosystem services are interconnected. By advancing our understanding of motivations of human behavior associated with the provision of environmental services this research project contributes to global environmental change, ecosystem services and livelihoods scholarship and to social-environmental sustainability. The findings of the research can help us to design better policies to jointly alleviate poverty, enhance resilience to environmental change and conserve the production of ecosystem services and biological diversity, both within and beyond the region of study.
